ferc_filing_data.tariff_title: FERC Power Sales and Reassignment of Transmission

record_data.record_title: Power Sales and Reassignment of Transmission Rights Tariff
record_data.record_plain_text:
Preamble Commonwealth Edison Company ("Company") offers to sell power and energy from time to time in accordance with and subject to the terms and conditions contained in this Tariff when Company and a Customer, as defined hereinafter, have reached agreement on specific transactions to be conducted hereunder. 1. Definitions 1.1. “Company" means Commonwealth Edison Company. 1.2. “Commission" or "FERC" means the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission or any successor federal agency having regulatory jurisdiction over this Tariff. 1.3. "Customer" means any Electric Utility for which Company has filed with the FERC a Service Agreement relating to service to such Electric Utility under this Tariff. 1.4. "Electric Utility" means a private or public corporation, governmental agency or authority, municipality, rural electric membership corporation or cooperative, or lawful association of any of the foregoing, that sells electric energy, to which it has title, at wholesale or retail, and that is subject to regulation with respect to rates or services under the laws of the state where such entity renders electric utility service, or pursuant to the Federal Power Act, or is legally exempted from such regulation; provided, however, that the term "Electric Utility" shall not include ultimate consumers of electric utility service. 1.5. "Energy" means the quantity of electricity produced or consumed over a period of time and is measured in megawatthours (MWh). 1.6. "Point of Delivery" ("POD") means a point of interconnection where Power and Energy to be delivered by Company will be made available to such Receiving Party. All physical interconnections with a single utility shall be considered a single POD, e.g., all of Company's interconnections with Wisconsin Electric Power Company shall be considered a single point. The POD shall be specified as mutually agreed upon by Company and Customer. 1.7. "Power" means the capability to perform work and is measured in megawatts (MW). 1.8. "Receiving Party” means, unless otherwise agreed, an entity other than Customer receiving at a Point of Delivery the Power and Energy to be purchased under this Tariff. Unless otherwise agreed, a Receiving Party must be directly connected to Edison's transmission system and may not, in any case, be a retail customer of Company, either in whole or in part. The Customer may be the Receiving Party or the Receiving Party may be another Electric Utility with whom the arrangements necessary for the transmission of power and energy to be sold under this Tariff have been made. 1.9. "Service Agreement" means the initial agreement, and any amendments or supplements thereto, entered into by Customer and Company for service under this Tariff. A Service Agreement may be unexecuted. If a Customer takes service under this Tariff, the Customer shall be deemed to have agreed to take and pay for service under this Tariff in accordance with and subject to the terms and conditions set forth herein, in the Power Sales Schedules hereto and in any Service Agreement filed with the FERC relating to service to such Customer. 2. Availability 2.1. Company shall sell Power and Energy under this Tariff when Company and a Customer have reached agreement on the rates and other terms and conditions applicable to a particular transaction. Such rates, terms and conditions shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of this Tariff and the service to be provided to the Customer shall be subject to the restrictions on service set forth in this Tariff and the applicable Power Sales Schedule. 3. Operations and Character of Service 3.1. Point of Delivery. Unless otherwise agreed, the POD for transactions under this Tariff is the POD between Company and the Receiving Party pursuant to an Interconnection Agreement between Company and such utility. Unless otherwise agreed, Customer shall be responsible for all arrangements with, including compensation to, other systems with respect to the transmission, from the POD, of Power and Energy sold to Customer under this Tariff. 3.2. Synchronous Operation. It is the intent of Company and Customer that the electric systems interconnected with Company or Customer be operated in synchronous fashion. If synchronous operation of such systems is interrupted because of reasons beyond the control of either Company or Customer, or because of scheduled construction or maintenance, Company and Customer shall cooperate with each other and with the intervening systems to remove the cause of such interruption as soon as practicable and restore such systems to a normal operating condition. 3.3. Character of Power and Energy. All electric Power and Energy delivered under this Tariff shall be of the character commonly known as three-phase, 60-hertz Power and Energy. 4. Services to be Rendered 4.1. Power Sales Schedule. Company offers to sell Firm Power, Short Term Power, General Purpose Energy, Negotiated Capacity, Spinning Reserve Service, Supplemental Reserve Service, and Losses and Backup Capacity Charge subject to the rates, terms and conditions set out in the following attached Power Sales Schedules':
Power Sales Schedule Type of Service 1 Firm Power 2 Short Term Power 3 General Purpose Energy 4 Negotiated Capacity 5 Spinning Reserve Service 6 Supplemental Reserve Service 7 Losses and Backup Capacity Charge
4.2. Sale, Assignment or Transfer of Transmission Rights Company offers to sell, assign or transfer transmission rights subject to the rates, terms and conditions set out in the Sale, Assignment or Transfer of Transmission Rights Schedule 8. 5. General Terms and Conditions 5.1. Delivery Arrangements. All deliveries of Power and Energy hereunder will be made through a POD designated by Company and Customer for the particular transaction at the time the transaction is scheduled or as otherwise designated by mutual agreement. 5.2. Scheduling. All Energy sold hereunder shall be delivered and billed on a scheduled basis in accordance with the applicable Power Sales Schedule and the agreed upon terms of a particular transaction. The minimum scheduled amount for any hourly transaction shall be 1 MW. The minimum scheduled amount in any hour for a daily transaction shall be 1 MW. All transactions shall be scheduled in increments of whole megawatts. Unless Company and Customer mutually agree otherwise, schedules for the delivery of Firm Power, Short Term Power, and Daily General Purpose Energy shall be set and agreed upon by Company and Customer by noon of the working day prior to the day on which service is to be provided. Unless Company and Customer mutually agree otherwise, schedules for the delivery of Hourly General Purpose Energy shall be set and agreed upon by Company and Customer in the hour prior to the hour during which service to be provided commences. Company will make a reasonable effort to accommodate any schedule changes requested by Customer but Company shall not be obligated hereunder to accept unreasonable requests for scheduling changes. Company and Customer shall designate to the other in writing the persons authorized to transact on its behalf hereunder and the scope of their authority, and shall provide the telephone and facsimile numbers which shall be employed for communications hereunder. 5.3. Transmission Service Arrangements. 5.3.1. Unless Company and Customer agree otherwise, Customer shall arrange for and assume full financial responsibility for all necessary transmission service from third parties. If such transmission service arranged for by Customer should also involve transmission directly or indirectly on the facilities of a utility system other than the system(s) in the contract path arranged by Customer, Customer will make any and all necessary arrangements for use of such facilities directly with such system or systems. To the extent that such other utilities seek to impose charges for such transmission service with respect to transactions under this Tariff, Company shall be under no obligation to collect charges on behalf of, or to remit payments to, any other utility in connection with the delivery of Power and Energy to Customer. As between Company and Customer, claims or demands made by other utilities arising out of a transaction hereunder in respect of the claimed use of the transmission systems of such other utilities shall be the sole responsibility of Customer. 5.3.2. Company and Customer may agree that Company will arrange and pay for any transmission service over facilities of third parties required for any transaction under this Tariff. Company and Customer shall agree upon the firmness of the third party transmission service to be arranged. In addition to other charges due Company under this Tariff, Customer shall reimburse Company for such third party transmission service charges, including any gross receipts or similar taxes paid by Company in connection with such third party service. 5.4. Billing. As soon as practicable after the end of each calendar month, Company shall render to Customer a bill for all charges due from Customer for such month under this Tariff and Customer shall pay such bill within 15 days after the receipt thereof. Payment will be deemed made on the day funds are wire transferred to Company's account or on the day Company is in receipt of Customer's check. Interest on amounts unpaid by the 15th day shall accrue at an annual rate equal to the prime rate for commercial loans, or equivalent, as set by Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Chicago, Illinois, or such other banking institution designated by Company, from such date until the date upon which payment is made. 5.5. Liability. Neither Company nor Customer shall be liable for damages resulting from the failure of the other to perform its obligations related to any transaction to be conducted hereunder. Company shall not be responsible for any consequential or incidental or indirect damages or loss of revenues or profits caused by any interruption. Customer shall remain liable to Company for demand or reservation charges associated with transactions agreed to prior to interruption except in such instances where it is Company's system which is the cause of the interruption. In circumstances where the interruption occurs on Company's system, compensation for demand or reservation charges shall be adjusted, if at all, as specified in the Power Sales Schedules attached hereto. No other entity is intended to be a third party beneficiary under this agreement and no cause of action, whether in tort, contract or otherwise may be based in whole or in part upon breach of this agreement by any entity other than Company and Customer. 5.6. Force Majeure. Neither Company nor Customer shall be in default with respect to any obligation hereunder, other than the payment of money, if prevented from fulfilling such obligation by reason of any cause beyond its reasonable control, including, but not limited to, outages or interruptions due to weather, accidents, equipment failures or threat of failure, strikes, civil unrest, injunctions or order of governmental authority having jurisdiction. If performance by Company or Customer has been prevented by such an event, the affected party shall promptly and diligently attempt to remove the cause of its failure to perform, except that neither Company nor Customer shall be obligated to agree to any quick settlement of any strike or labor disturbance, which, in the affected party's opinion, may be inadvisable or detrimental. Nothing herein shall be construed as permitting a Company or Customer to continue to fail to perform after such cause has been removed. 5.7. Indemnity. For the purpose of this Section 5.7 only, the term "party" shall include each party transacting under this Tariff together with the party's directors, officers, employees, and agents. To the extent permitted by law, each party shall indemnify, save harmless, and defend the other party from and against any loss, liability, costs, expenses, suits, actions, claims and all other obligations arising out of injuries to persons or damage to property caused by or in any way attributable to the ownership or operation of its facilities, except that this obligation shall not apply to any liabilities arising from the other party's sole negligence or that portion of any liabilities that arise out of the other party's contributing negligent acts or omissions. 5.8. Records. For a period of at least five years, Company and Customer shall maintain records of all transactions hereunder. Company and Customer shall make such records available for inspection and audit by the other party at reasonable times and places at the other party's request. 5.9. Successors and Assigns. Any Service Agreement governing service provided to a Customer under this Tariff shall be binding upon the respective parties, their successors and assigns, on and after the effective date of such Service Agreement. Such Service Agreement, whether in whole or in part, may not be assigned to any party or any third party without the written consent of the other party. Such consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. 5.10. Notices. All notices provided to Company shall be addressed as follows:
Director, T & D Regulatory Services T & D Regulatory Services Department Commonwealth Edison Company One First National Plaza, 34 FNW 10 South Dearborn Street Chicago, IL 60603
The position and address specified above may be changed by written notice to Customer.
5.11. Regulation. This Tariff shall not become effective until accepted for filing by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission without change or condition. 5.12. Effective Date. Service provided under this Tariff shall become effective on the date specified in the Service Agreement, or such other date as assigned by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. 6. Disputes 6.1. Initial Resolution In the event of a dispute between Company (sometimes referred to as a party for purposes of this Section) and Customer (sometimes also referred to as a party for purposes of this Section) arising out of or in connection with this Tariff or Service Agreement, the following shall apply:
(a) If the dispute is not resolved within 30 days of service of written notice by one of the parties to the other of such dispute, each party will appoint one of its officers to an ad hoc committee of two. Such officers shall have settlement authority and shall not have been directly involved in the dispute. They shall attempt to mutually resolve the dispute.
(b) If the dispute is not resolved within 90 days of the service of the notice in subsection (a), the parties may mutually agree that the matter be submitted to arbitration in the manner hereinafter provided. In no event shall a dispute be submitted to arbitration after the date when institution of legal or equitable proceedings based on such dispute would be barred by the applicable statute of limitation.
During the course of resolving the dispute, the parties to the Service Agreement shall allow the services provided under this Tariff to continue pending such resolution. 6.2. Submission to Arbitration. If the parties agree to submit a dispute to arbitration, such submission to arbitration shall be the sole remaining means to resolve the dispute. 6.3. Arbitration Rules. The dispute shall be arbitrated pursuant to the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association. The arbitration proceedings shall be conducted in Washington, D.C., or in another mutually acceptable city, at a place to be determined by the arbitrator. 6.4. Arbitration Request. The party to the Service Agreement proposing arbitration shall serve a request for arbitration in writing upon the other party, which request shall contain a statement setting forth the nature of the dispute, the amount involved, if any, and the remedy sought. If Company and Customer agree to arbitration, they shall endeavor to agree upon and appoint one person to act as sole arbitrator. If the parties fail so to agree within a period of 15 days from the date they agree to arbitration, the party calling for the arbitration, upon five days' written notice to the other party, may apply to the American Arbitration Association for the appointment of a single arbitrator, skilled in the particular matter which is the subject of dispute. 6.5. Procedures. The sole arbitrator shall establish the procedure and procedural schedule for the arbitration and shall afford adequate opportunity to the parties to the arbitration to present information with respect to the question or questions submitted for arbitration and may request further information from either party to the Service Agreement. A complete record shall be kept of all proceedings. The arbitrator shall make its award promptly, and no later than 30 days from the date of closing the hearing, but the parties hereto may agree, at any time prior to the making of such award, on an extension of such period, whether or not previously extended. All awards shall be made in writing, and an original of the award shall be furnished to each of the parties. 6.6. Expenses. Each party shall pay for its own expenses. If there is arbitration, all other costs incurred in connection with such arbitration shall be paid in equal parts by the parties hereto, unless the award shall specify a different division of the costs. 6.7. Awards. The findings and award of the sole arbitrator shall be final and conclusive with respect to the question or questions submitted for arbitration and shall be binding upon the parties to the Service Agreement. Judgment upon an award rendered by the arbitrator may be entered in any court of competent jurisdiction. 7. Changes in Rates, Charges, Classifications, Service, Rules, Regulations or Service Agreements 7.1. Rate Regulation: The provision of service by Company under this Tariff, the Power Sales Schedules attached to this Tariff, and any Service Agreement are subject to the jurisdiction of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Nothing contained in this Tariff or any Service Agreement entered into hereunder shall be construed as affecting or limiting in any way the right of Company unilaterally to file with the Commission, or make application to the Commission for, changes in rates, charges, classifications, or service, or any rule or regulation relating thereto, in this Tariff, the attached Power Sales Schedules or Service Agreement under Section 205 of the Federal Power Act pursuant to the Commission's rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, or under other applicable statutes or regulations. 8. Governing Law 8.1. The validity and meaning of this Tariff and any Service Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of Illinois. 9. After Termination or Cancellation 9.1. The applicable provisions of this Tariff and any Service Agreement entered into under this Tariff shall continue in effect after termination or cancellation thereof to the extent necessary to provide for final billing, billing adjustments and payments. FORM OF SERVICE AGREEMENT This Service Agreement, dated as of , is entered into by and between Commonwealth Edison Company ("Company"), and __________________________________________ (“Customer”.)
Company will make available to Customer the coordination services identified in Company's FERC Power Sales and Reassignment of Transmission Rights Tariff PSRT-l (hereinafter referred to as the Tariff) subject to Company's reaching mutual agreement with Customer for each transaction under the Tariff. Company shall provide such services at rates and charges determined in accordance with the Tariff and subject to the terms and conditions set forth in the Tariff.
Any notice or request made to or by Company or Customer regarding this Service Agreement shall be made in writing and shall be telecommunicated or delivered either in person, or by prepaid mail to the representative of the other party as indicated below. Such representative and address for notices or requests may be changed from time to time by notice by one party to the other.

September 13, 1999 Peoples Energy Service Corporation January 24, 2000 FIRM POWER 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff.
2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. Firm Power is Power and associated Energy from generating capacity in Company's system that may from time to time be sold to Customer for the purpose of providing increased flexibility in the planning and installation of Customer's generating capacity additions. The supply of Firm Power is considered as firm as service to Company's other non-interruptible load. This transaction shall be included in the determination of Company's planning reserve requirement.
2.2. Customer, by giving Company advance notice, may reserve for periods of one or more months, such electric Power as Company may have and is willing to make available as Firm Power. To reserve Firm Power, Customer shall specify in its notice to Company the number of megawatts it desires to reserve and the period of reservation. Company shall, based upon its sole judgment, promptly signify the extent of its ability and willingness to make the requested reservation and the capacity charge which will be applicable.
2.3. Unless otherwise specifically agreed with Customer, Company intends continuous availability of Firm Power and Energy and the supply will be subject to curtailment or interruption only in extreme emergencies caused by events or circumstances beyond the control of Company and only in proportion to the amount that Company's other non-interruptible load is curtailed.
2.4. Any request or any acknowledgment of such request that may be given orally initially shall be confirmed in writing by Customer and such confirmation shall normally be forwarded in a reasonable time but not later than eight days following the day such oral request or acknowledgment is given.
2.5. During the period that Firm Power has been reserved as provided above, it shall be the responsibility of Customer to schedule, in advance, the deliveries of Energy associated therewith and of Company to deliver such Energy in amounts up to the number of megawatts reserved.
3. Compensation
3.1. Compensation for the supply of Firm Power and associated Firm Energy shall be made at the following rates: 3.1.1. Firm Power: 3.1.1.1. At the rate of up to $17,000.00 per megawatt reserved per month. 3.1.2. Energy Charge: 3.1.2.1. For Energy generated by Company:
110% of the Out-of-Pocket Cost ("OPC") (OPC includes all operating, maintenance, taxes on gross receipts, the cost of transmission losses, and other expenses incurred that would not have been incurred by Company if the Energy had not been supplied) of supplying Firm Energy called for during such period. 3.1.2.2. For Energy purchased from a third party to supply Firm Energy called for during such period: a. The amount paid by Company, plus b. $1.00 per megawatthour for difficult-to-quantify costs, plus c. The cost of transmission losses and taxes on gross receipts incurred which would not otherwise have been incurred. SHORT TERM POWER
1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff.
2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. Customer, by giving Company reasonable notice may reserve, for periods of one or more weeks of seven consecutive days each or for periods of one or more days, such electric Power as Company may at such time have and be willing to make available as Short Term Power. Short Term Power is intended to be relied upon with the same degree of assurance as that expected from Company's own generating capacity, but does not include reserve capacity. The Company shall be the sole judge as to the amounts available and periods of availability. 2.1.1. Customer shall specify in its notice to Company the number of megawatts which it desires to reserve, the period of reservation and the anticipated schedule of delivery. Company shall promptly signify the extent of its ability and willingness to comply with the provisions of such notice. Arrangements for the reservation of Short Term Power that are made orally shall be promptly confirmed in writing by Customer. 2.1.2. During the period that Short Term Power has been reserved, as provided-above, it shall be the responsibility of Customer to schedule, in advance, the delivery of Short Term Energy associated therewith and the responsibility of Company to deliver such energy in amounts up to the number of megawatts of Short Term Power reserved. However, in the event conditions arise during such period which could not have been reasonably foreseen at the time said Power was reserved and such conditions would cause the delivery of such Short Term Energy to be burdensome to Company, Company has the right to reduce the number of megawatts reserved of Short Term Power to any amount specified and for any portion of such period. Notice of such reduction will be made by expeditious means to Customer as far in advance as practicable, and Customer shall promptly comply with the decision of the Company.
3. Compensation
3.1. Compensation for Weekly or Daily Short Term Power shall be made at the following rates: 3.1.1. Weekly Short Term Power 3.1.1.1. At the rate of up to $2,800.00 per megawatt reserved per such week. 3.1.1.2. In the event the amount of reserved Weekly Short Term Power is reduced upon request of Company, the demand charge shall be reduced by one-sixth (1/6) of Company's weekly demand rate per megawatt of reduction for each day (other than Sunday) during which any reduction is in effect. 3.1.2. Daily Short Term Power 3.1.2.1. At the rate of up to $560.00 per megawatt reserved per such day. 3.1.2.2. In the event the amount of reserved Daily Short Term Power is reduced upon request of Company, the demand charge shall be reduced to zero per megawatt of reduction for each day during which such reduction is made. 3.1.2.3. Notwithstanding the rate stated in Subsection 3.1.2.1, the total demand charge revenue collected by Company under such subsection for Daily Short Term Power in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Daily Short Term Power reserved on any day in the seven-day period, and $2,800.00.
3.2. The Customer shall pay for all Short Term Energy delivered at the following rates: 3.2.1. For Energy generated by Company: a. Up to 110% of the Out-of-Pocket Cost ("OPC") (OPC includes all operating, maintenance, taxes on gross receipts, the cost of transmission losses and other expenses incurred that would not have been incurred by Company if the Energy had not been supplied) of supplying Short Term Energy called for during such period. 3.2.2. For Energy purchased from a third party to supply the Short Term Energy called for during such period: a. The amount paid by Company, plus b. $1.00 per megawatthour for difficult-to-quantify costs, plus c. The cost of transmission losses and taxes on gross receipts incurred which would not otherwise have been incurred. 3.3. Notwithstanding the rates stated in Subsections 3.1.1, 3.1.2, and 3.2.1, the total energy charge for each transaction shall not be less than 100% of the OPC of supplying the Short Term Energy when such transaction is scheduled. GENERAL PURPOSE ENERGY 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. It is recognized that from time to time occasions will arise when the circumstances contemplated under other service schedules which are part of this Tariff do not exist, but at the same time Company may have Energy (herein called "General Purpose Energy") which it is willing to make available from surplus capacity on its own system that can be utilized advantageously by Customer. Hourly General Purpose Energy may be arranged to provide the supply of electricity scheduled hour-to-hour. Daily General Purpose Energy may be arranged to provide the supply of electricity for one or more days. 2.2. It shall be the responsibility of Customer to initiate the receipt and delivery of General Purpose Energy. Customer shall inform the Company of the extent to which it desires to use General Purpose Energy, and whenever Company determines in its own judgment that it has General Purpose Energy available, schedules providing the periods and quantities of, and price for, Energy to be delivered shall be arranged upon mutual agreement. 2.3. Company may reduce or discontinue the supply of Hourly General Purpose Energy at any time. To the extent possible, however, Company shall advise Customer of its intention to reduce materially or discontinue the supply. 2.4. In the event of an emergency or change in operating condition on Company's system, Company shall be under no obligation to continue the supply of Daily General Purpose Energy for more than three hours after it has notified Customer of its intention to discontinue such supply. Customer will use its best efforts to release Company from any obligation under this section as soon as possible. 3. Compensation 3.1. General Purpose Energy delivered under this schedule shall be settled for as follows: 3.1.1. For Energy which is generated by Company to supply an Hourly or Daily General Purpose Energy transaction:
a. Up to 110% of the Out-of-Pocket ("OPC") (OPC includes all operating, maintenance, taxes on gross receipts, the cost of transmission losses and other expenses incurred that would not have been incurred by Company if the Energy had not been supplied) of supplying General Purpose Energy called for during such period, plus b. Up to $35.00 per megawatthour (this element of the charges for any one day shall total to no more than the product of $560.00 times the highest average number of megawatts delivered in any hour during the day). 3.1.2. For Energy which is purchased by Company from a third party for economic reasons to meet system needs but in subsequent system resource accounting calculations is determined to have been used to supply a Daily General Purpose Energy transaction and for which Company stands by to supply from its own resources :
a. The amount paid by Company, plus b. The cost of transmission losses and taxes on gross receipts incurred which would not otherwise have been incurred, plus c. $1.00 per megawatthour for difficult-to-quantify costs, plus d. Up to $35.00 per megawatthour (this element of the charge for any day not to exceed the product of $560.00 times the highest average number of megawatts delivered in any hour during the day). 3.1.3. For Energy which is purchased by Company from a third party for economic reasons to meet system needs but in subsequent system resource accounting calculations is determined to have been used to supply an Hourly General Purpose Energy transaction:
a. The amount paid by Company, plus b. The cost of transmission losses and taxes on gross receipts incurred that would not otherwise have been incurred, plus c. $1.00 per megawatthour for difficult-to-quantify costs, plus d. 5.00 per megawatthour for Energy transmitted during on-peak hours and $1.50 per megawatthour for Energy transmitted during off-peak hours (the total of such amounts for any one day not to exceed $80.00 times the highest average number of megawatts delivered in any hour during the day). 3.2. Notwithstanding the rates stated in Subsection 3.1.1, the total charge for each transaction shall not be less than 100% of the estimated OPC of supplying the General Purpose Energy when such transaction is scheduled. 3.3. Notwithstanding the rates stated in Subsections 3.1.1 b. and 3.1.2 d., the total revenue collected by Company under such subsection in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest average number of megawatts delivered in any hour during the seven-day period, and $2,800.00. 3.4. Notwithstanding the rate stated in Subsection 3.1.3 d., the total revenue collected by Company under such subsection in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest average number of megawatts delivered in any hour during the seven-day period, and $400.00. 3.5. Notwithstanding the rates stated in Subsections 3.1.2 and 3.1.3, the price per megawatthour charged by Company for each transaction shall not exceed the price per megawatthour agreed to prior to the start of the transaction pursuant to Subsection 2.2. 4. Period Definition 4.1. The on-peak period is defined as all hours during the period starting 6:00 a.m. and ending 10:00 p.m. Central Standard Time or Central Daylight Saving Time (whichever is in legal force on Company's system) of each day except all hours on Saturday, Sunday, and the days on which the following holidays are generally observed: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. Any hour not falling within the on-peak period shall be considered to be in the off-peak period.
NEGOTIATED CAPACITY 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. Negotiated Capacity is capacity and associated energy which Customer may purchase from Company for the purpose of obtaining a supply of power during the period covered by a commitment. It is intended to provide both Customer and Company with a wide range of flexibility in structuring transactions which are mutually beneficial, including negotiable degrees of firmness, variable capacity charges and variable time durations. Company and Customer may also negotiate an option ("Option") to purchase capacity and associated energy at a specified price within a specified time period, such payments to be made when and as agreed. Company and Customer may also negotiate a Diversity Exchange, that is, the exchange of capacity and energy in one period for capacity and energy in another period. 2.2. Customer may reserve such Negotiated Capacity as Company may have and is willing to make available, may secure an Option on capacity that Company may have and is willing to place under an Option, or may arrange a Diversity Exchange if Company determines it both can use the energy offered and is willing to make available the energy to be returned. Company and Customer shall agree on the number of megawatts and the period of reservation, option or exchange. 2.3. The degree of firmness, which may range from firm service equivalent to the supply to Company's native load requirements to non-firm service, shall be mutually agreed upon by both parties at the time the power is reserved or placed under option. Capacity classified as non-firm shall, at a minimum, be treated by the Company as having a higher degree of reliability than sales to other systems which do not involve a sale of capacity (i.e., Hourly General Purpose Energy). 2.4. Any request or any acknowledgment of such request that may initially be given orally shall be confirmed in writing by Customer, if requested by Company. Such confirmation shall normally be forwarded in a reasonable time but not later than eight days following the day such oral request or acknowledgement is given. 2.5. During or in advance of the period that Negotiated Capacity has been reserved or power and energy are to be delivered upon exercise of the Option, or exchange power and energy are to be delivered to Customer, it shall be the responsibility of Customer to schedule, in advance, the deliveries of Energy associated therewith, and the responsibility of Company to deliver such Energy, pursuant to the degree of firmness established in Section 2.3, in amounts up to the number of megawatts reserved. 3. Compensation 3.1. Compensation for the supply of Negotiated Capacity and associated Energy shall be made at the following rates: 3.1.1. Capacity supplied by Company: a. At the rate of up to $204,000 per megawatt reserved per year, or b. At the rate of up to $17,000 per megawatt reserved per month, or c. At the rate of up to $3,900 per megawatt reserved per week, or d. At the rate of up to $780 per megawatt reserved per day, subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Negotiated Capacity reserved on any day in the seven-day period, and $3,900, or e. At the rate of up to $49 per megawatt reserved per hour subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Negotiated Capacity reserved in any hour in the seven-day period, and $3,900. In addition, the total demand charge in any day shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Negotiated Capacity reserved in any hour in the day, and $780.
3.1.2. Capacity purchased from a Third Party for a specific transaction when Company is the transmitting Party: a. At the rate of up to $20,400 per megawatt reserved per year, plus the demand. charge paid by Company to the third party, or b. At the rate of up to $1,700 per megawatt reserved per month, plus the demand charge paid by Company to the third party, or c. At the rate of up to $392 per megawatt reserved per week, plus the demand charge paid by Company to the third party, or d. At the rate of up to $78 per megawatt reserved per day, plus the demand charge paid by Company to the third party subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of negotiated capacity reserved on any day in the seven-day period, and $392, or e. At the rate of up to $4.90 per megawatt reserved per hour, plus the demand charge paid by Company to the third party, subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Negotiated Capacity reserved in any hour in the seven-day period, and $392. In addition, the total demand charge in any day shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Negotiated Capacity reserved in any hour of the day, and $78. 3.1.3. Energy Charge: 3.1.3.1. For Energy generated by Company: The energy charge per megawatthour delivered is Company's actual Out-of-Pocket Cost ("OPC") plus an adder up to 10% of such cost (OPC includes all operating, maintenance, taxes on gross receipts, the cost of transmission losses, and other expenses incurred that would not have been incurred by Company if the Energy had not been supplied) of supplying energy called for during such period. 3.1.3.2. For Energy purchased from a third party to supply Energy called for during such period: a. The amount paid by Company, plus b. Up to $1.00 per megawatt for difficult-to-quantify costs provided, however, that in the event Company purchases third-party energy for more than 52 consecutive weeks to meet its obligation to Customer, no adder will be charged after the 52nd week; plus c. The cost of transmission losses and taxes on gross receipts incurred which would not otherwise have been incurred. 3.2. Customer Supplied Fuel: At Customer's request, but subject to Company's agreement, Customer may supply fuel to Company in exchange for capacity and associated energy. Company and Customer will agree on -the value of the delivered fuel and a negotiated price for the capacity and associated energy. In no event, shall the total compensation to Company (which shall include the agreed value of the fuel) exceed the cumulative rate caps for capacity and energy set out in Sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.3.1 or 3.1.3.2, as appropriate. 3.3. Compensation for an Option on Company capacity shall, in no event, exceed the capacity charge for Negotiated Capacity set out above in Section 3.11. Upon exercise of the Option, the total of any additional charges for capacity and energy plus the option payment shall not exceed the cumulative rate caps for capacity and energy set out in Section 3.1.1 and Sections 3.1.3.1 or 3.1.3.2, as appropriate. 3.4. Rate of exchange: At the time a Diversity Exchange is agreed to, Company and Customer shall agree on the ratio of exchange between off-peak and on-peak or other supply periods. In no event shall the value to Company of energy received (as measured by Company's avoided OPC at the time of receipt) exceed the cumulative rate caps for capacity and energy set out in Sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.3.1 or 3.1.3.2, as appropriate. 3.5. Fixed rate per megawatthour: Company and Customer may agree to fixed rates per megawatthour for the term of an individual transaction provided, however, that in no case shall the compensation, over the term of the transaction, exceed the cumulative rate caps for capacity and energy set out in sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.3.1 or 3.1.3.2, as appropriate.
SPINNING RESERVE SERVICE 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. Company will provide Spinning Reserve Service when Company and Customer agree. Spinning Reserve Service is needed to serve load immediately in the event of a system contingency. Spinning Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line and loaded at less than maximum output, ready to serve additional demand, and which can be fully applied in 10 minutes. 3. Compensation 3.1. Compensation for the supply of Spinning Reserve Service and associated Energy shall be made at the following rates: 3.1.1. Availability Charge: a. At the rate of up to $8,000 per megawatt reserved per month, or b. At the rate of up to $l,846 per megawatt reserved per week, or c. At the rate of up to $369 per megawatt reserved per day, subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of Megawatts of Spinning Reserve Service reserved on any day in the seven-day period, and $1,846, or d. At the rate of up to $23.08 per megawatt reserved per hour subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Spinning Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the seven-day period, and $1,846. In addition, the total demand charge in any day shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Spinning Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the day, and $369. 3.1.2. A Customer requesting Spinning Reserve Service under this Schedule 5 must arrange for or have made arrangements for transmission service equal to the amount of Spinning Reserve Service reserved. 3.2. When Customer calls for Spinning Reserve Capacity to be delivered, the energy charge shall be as follows: 3.2.1. For Energy generated by Company: a. The energy charge per megawatthour delivered is Company's actual Out-of-Pocket Cost ("OPC") plus an adder up to 10% of such cost (OPC includes all operating, maintenance, taxes on gross receipts, the cost of transmission losses, the cost of sulfur dioxide emission allowances, and other expenses incurred that would not have been incurred by Company if the Energy had not been supplied) of supplying energy called for during such period. 3.2.2. For Energy purchased from a third party to supply energy called for during such period: a. The amount paid by Company, plus b. The cost of transmission losses and taxes on gross receipts incurred which would not otherwise have been incurred. 3.3. When Customer calls for Spinning Reserve Capacity to be delivered, the Availability Charge shall be reduced by an Energy True Up Adjustment as follows: a. At the rate of $.36 per megawatthour subject to the limitation that the Energy True Up Adjustment in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the amount of megawatthours delivered in the seven-day period, and $28.70. In addition, the Energy True Up Adjustment in any day shall not exceed the product of the amount of megawatthours delivered in the day, and $5.74.
SUPPLEMENTAL RESERVE SERVICE 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. Company will provide Supplemental Reserve Service when Company and Customer agree. Supplemental Reserve Service is needed to serve load in the event of a system contingency; however, it is not available immediately to serve load but rather within 10 minutes. Supplemental Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line but unloaded which can be fully applied in 10 minutes, or by quick-start generation capable of serving demand within 10 minutes. 3. Compensation 3.1. Compensation for the supply of Supplemental Reserve Service and associated Energy shall be made at the following rates: 3.1.1. Demand Charge: a. At the rate of up to $2,260 per megawatt reserved per month, or b. At the rate of up to $521 per megawatt reserved per week, or c. At the rate of up to $104 per megawatt reserved per day, subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Supplemental Reserve service reserved on any day in the seven-day period, and $521, or d. d. At the rate of up to $6.52 per megawatt reserved per hour subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Supplemental Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the seven-day period, and $521. In addition, the total demand charge in any day shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Supplemental Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the day, and $104. 3.1.2. A Customer requesting Supplemental Reserve Service under this Schedule 6 must arrange for or have made arrangements for transmission service equal to the amount of Supplemental Reserve Service reserved. 3.1.3. Energy Charge: For Energy generated by Company: The energy charge per megawatthour delivered is Company's actual Out-of-Pocket Cost ("OPC") plus an adder up to 10% of such cost (OPC includes all operating, maintenance, taxes on gross receipts, the cost-Of transmission losses, the cost of sulfur dioxide emission allowances, and other expenses incurred that would not have been incurred by Company if the Energy had not been supplied) of supplying energy called for during such period. For Energy purchased from a third party to supply Energy called for during such period: a. The amount paid by Company, plus b. The cost of transmission losses and taxes on gross receipts incurred which would not otherwise have been incurred.
LOSSES-AND BACKUP CAPACITY CHARGE 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. Company will provide capacity and energy requested by Customer at the rates, and on the terms and conditions, set forth in Power Sales Schedule 4 of this Tariff, when generating capacity is available and provision of such service will not unreasonably impair reliability of Company's transmission system.
SALE, ASSIGNMENT OR TRANSFER OF TRANSMISSION RIGHTS 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1. Company may sell, assign or transfer to Customer, pursuant to an agreement to be negotiated between them, all or a portion of Company's rights to the use of the transmission system of a transmission provider (Transmission Provider) that company has reserved for its own use under a Service Agreement with the Transmission Provider or has acquired from another customer of Transmission Provider, including capacity that Company has reserved or acquired for its own use on Company's transmission system under Company's Open Access Transmission Tariff; provided, however, that Customer is an eligible customer under Transmission Provider's transmission service tariff or other rate schedules pursuant to which the transmission service rights to be transferred to Customer were originally obtained from Transmission Provider. Except as to price, the terms and conditions under which Company will sell, assign or transfer such transmission service rights to Customer shall be the terms and conditions governing the original grant by Transmission Provider of transmission service rights. 3. Compensation 3.1. Company shall sell, assign or transfer such rights to Customer at a price not to exceed the highest of (1) the original transmission rate charged to Company, (2) the Transmission Provider's maximum stated firm transmission rate at the time of the sale, assignment or transfer to Customer or (3) Company's own opportunity costs capped at the cost of expansion at the time of the sale, assignment or transfer to Customer. 3.2. In the event that Company (Wholesale Marketing Function) has secured capacity on Company's (Transmission Provider's) transmission system under Company's (Transmission Provider's) Open Access Transmission Tariff ("OATT") and Company (Wholesale Marketing Function) sells, assigns or transfers such capacity pursuant to this Sale, Assignment or Transfer of Transmission Rights Service Schedule, Company (Transmission Provider) will adhere to all the non-rate terms and conditions of its OATT which would be applicable were the transaction a direct sale of capacity by Company (Transmission Provider) rather than a sale, assignment or transfer by Company (Wholesale Marketing Function). Prior to any sale, assignment or transfer at a price based on opportunity costs, Company (Wholesale Marketing Function) will file under section 205 of the Federal Power Act and secure Commission permission to place such price into effect.
Emergency Service 1. Duration 1.1 This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services To Be Rendered 2.1 When an emergency exists, Company may provide Emergency Energy, or may purchase energy from the system of a Third Party for resale to Customer. 2.2 Emergency Energy is defined as (a) energy purchased during any period in which the generation and transmission facilities available and in service on Customer's system, when combined with purchases of power available from other systems (not including such Emergency Energy), are inadequate to permit Customer to meet its system obligations; or (b) energy purchased by Customer for the purpose of selling Emergency Energy to another party experiencing such conditions. 2.3 Such energy shall be scheduled as soon as possible after the occurrence and shall be furnished by Company or in such amounts as, in its sole judgment, it can supply. Having begun such delivery, Company may curtail, restrict or discontinue delivery hereunder whenever, in its sole judgment, such curtailment, restriction or discontinuance shall be necessary in the conduct of its other business or affairs, or its operations pertaining thereto. Notice of such curtailment, restriction or discontinuance will be made by most expeditious means to Customer as far in advance as practicable and Customer shall promptly comply with the decision of Company. 3. Compensation 3.1 Compensation for the supply of Emergency Service shall be as follows: 3.1.1 For energy generated by Company, the greater of: a. $100.00 per megawatthour, or b. The Company's actual Out-of-Pocket cost ("OPC") to supply such energy plus an adder of 10% of such cost. OPC includes all operating, maintenance, taxes on gross receipts, the cost of sulfur dioxide emission allowances, transmission losses and other incurred that would not have been incurred by Company if the energy had not been supplied. 3.1.2. For Emergency Energy purchased by Company from a Third Party, the greater of: a. $100.00 per megawatthour, or b. The amount paid to the Third Party, plus the taxes on gross receipts incurred which would not otherwise have been incurred. 3.2 A Customer requesting Emergency Service under this Schedule 9 must arrange for or have made arrangements for transmission service equal to the amount of Emergency Service reserved. 3.3. Transmission: 3.3.1. On Company's system: Company or Customer requesting Emergency Service under this Schedule 9 shall arrange for transmission service, equal to the amount of Emergency Service reserved, under Company's Open Access Transmission Tariff ("OATT") rates, shown for ease of reference in Appendix A to this Tariff. 3.3.2. On the system of a third party: Unless otherwise agreed, Customer shall arrange for any transmission service required over third-party systems beyond Company Point(s) of Delivery. 3.4. Ancillary Services: If ancillary services provided by Company are required in connection with any sale of Emergency Service under this Schedule 9, Company or the Customer requesting such Emergency Service shall arrange for such ancillary services under Company's OATT, shown for ease of reference in Appendix A to this Tariff, or Customer may arrange to purchase any required ancillary services from a third party. Emergency Redispatch Service 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services to Be Rendered 2.1. When Company receives notice that an electric utility (Customer) must curtail or interrupt firm load (Capacity Emergency) due to Customer's inability to receive energy because of a transmission constraint on the transmission system of a transmission provider other than Company, and such transmission constraint could be relieved in whole or in part by Company's operating its generating units out of economic order, or foregoing existing or contracted for purchases or sales, Company shall, if practicable, operate its generating units in a manner designed to alleviate such transmission constraint to the extent possible to avoid or minimize the Capacity Emergency (Emergency Redispatch). 2.2. If practicable and Emergency Redispatch can be made available by Company without interrupting or curtailing any native load customer or firm transmission customer being served by Company, Emergency Redispatch shall be initiated as soon as possible after the Company receives notice from a Customer, NERC or a security coordinator for a Regional Reliability Council of a Capacity Emergency and shall be accomplished by Company in a manner consistent with the requirements of NERC and MAIN. Company may terminate such Emergency Redispatch, in whole or in part, at any time, when in its sole judgment such action is necessary to continue to serve Company's customers, preserve the integrity of the interconnected transmission system or otherwise maintain system reliability, or when such termination is required to adhere to the requirements of NERC and MAIN. 3. Compensation 3.1. For Emergency Redispatch by Company, the Customer shall pay Company the greater of:
a. $100.00 per megawatthour of the increase in output of the out of merit generating units, or b. the sum of: (1) the difference between (a) the cost incurred to increase the output of the out of merit units and (b) the cost that would have been incurred in generating or purchasing the same amount of energy had Company not engaged in Emergency Redispatch or the difference between (c) the savings experienced from decreasing the output of generating units and (d) the coat incurred in replacing that generation: and (2) the lost profit on sales foregone to accomplish the Emergency Redispatch. Company's lost profit is the difference between the sale price negotiated by Company and the variable costs Company would have incurred in connection with the cancelled or interrupted sale; and (3) estimated costs in modifying the maintenance schedule of one or more generators in order to operate those generators. 4. Information in Support of Individual Transactions 4.1. Upon written request of the Customer, Company shall provide the Customer with information sufficient to permit the Customer to verify its bill for Emergency Redispatch service. Unless otherwise mutually agreed, Company shall provide such information within 35 days of Company's receipt in writing of a request from Customer for such information.Third-Party Redispatch Service 1. Duration 1.1. This schedule shall continue in effect throughout the duration of the Tariff of which it is a part, unless and until changed pursuant to the Tariff. 2. Services to Be Rendered 2.1. Company may, at its discretion, provide Third-Party Redispatch Service at the request of another transmission provider (Customer) where that transmission provider is facing curtailment or interruption of transmission service that it is providing and that transmission provider determines that such curtailment or interruption can be avoided in whole or in part by the Company operating its generating units out of economic order, or foregoing existing or contracted for purchases or sales. 3. Compensation 3.1. The charge for Third-Party Redispatch Service shall be as follows:
a. The sum of: (1) the difference between (a) the estimated cost incurred to increase the output of out of merit units and (b) the estimated cost that would have been incurred in generating or purchasing the same amount of energy had Company not engaged in Non-Firm Redispatch or the difference between (c) the savings experienced from decreasing the output of generating units and (d) the cost incurred in replacing that generation; and (2) the lost profit on sales foregone to accomplish the Non-Firm Redispatch. Company's lost profit is the difference between the sale price negotiated by Company and the estimated variable costs Company would have incurred in connection with the cancelled or interrupted sale; and (3) estimated costs incurred in modifying the maintenance schedule of one or more generators in order to operate those generators; and b. 10% of the charge in section 3.1.a above. 4. Information in Support of Individual Transactions 4.1. Upon written request of the Customer, Company shall provide the Customer with information sufficient to permit the Customer to verify its bill for Third-Party Redispatch Service. Unless otherwise mutually agreed, Company shall provide such information within 35 days of Company's receipt in writing of a request from Customer for such information. 5. Implementation. 5.1. To provide Third-Party Redispatch Service, Company will implement the changes in Company's utilization of its power supply resources that Customer agrees will assist Customer in avoiding the interruption or curtailment of transmission service that Customer provides to another party or parties. 5.2. Because Company has no control over the use by others of the interconnected transmission network in the upper Midwest, Company cannot assure that actions by others will not counteract the relief provided by Company in providing Third-Party Redispatch Service.
APPENDIX A
PSRT-1, Appendix A Commonwealth Edison Company Appendix A TRANSMISSION AND ANCILLARY SERVICES RATES Attached are copies of Schedules 1-10 from Commonwealth's Open Access Transmission Tariff (ancillary service and point-to-point transmission service charges).
SCHEDULE 1
Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service
This service is required to schedule the movement of power through, out of, within, or into a Control Area. This service can be provided only by the operator of the Control Area in which the transmission facilities used for transmission service are located. Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service is to be provided directly by the Transmission Provider (if the Transmission Provider is the Control Area operator). The Transmission Customer must purchase this service from the Transmission Provider. The charges for Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service shall be up to the rates set forth below:
Point-to-Point Transmission Service Annual Charge $1.0832 per kWMonthly Charge $0.0903 per kW Weekly Charge $0.0208 per kW Daily Charge $0.00298 per kWHourly Charge $0.000124 per kW
Network Integration Transmission Service Annual Charge $1.0832 per kW Monthly Charge $0.0903 per kW Gross receipts taxes and FERC annual charges (18 CFR § 382) shall apply in addition to the rates shown above.
SCHEDULE 2
Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service
In order to maintain transmission voltages on the Transmission Provider's transmission facilities within acceptable limits, generation facilities under the control of the control area operator are operated to produce (or absorb) reactive power. Thus, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service must be provided for each transaction on the Transmission Provider's transmission facilities. The amount of Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service that must be supplied with respect to the Transmission Customer's transaction will be determined based on the reactive power support necessary to maintain transmission voltages within limits that are generally accepted in the region and consistently adhered to by the Transmission Provider. Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service is to be provided directly by the Transmission Provider (if the Transmission Provider is the Control Area operator). The Transmission Customer must purchase this service from the Transmission Provider. The charges for such service shall be up to the rates set forth below.
Point-to-Point Transmission Service: $0.05720 per kW Monthly Cost $0.01320 per kW Weekly Cost $0.00264 per kW Daily Cost (with weekly cap) $0.00017 per kWh Hourly Cost (with daily and weekly cap) Network Integration Transmission Service: $0.05720 per kW Monthly Cost Gross receipts taxes and FERC annual charges (18 C.F.R. § 382) shall apply in addition to the rates shown above.
SCHEDULE 3
Regulation and Frequency Response Service 1.0 Regulation and Frequency Response Service is necessary to provide for the continuous balancing of resources (generation and interchange) with load and for maintaining scheduled Interconnection frequency at sixty cycles per second (60 Hz). Regulation and Frequency Response Service is accomplished by committing on-line generation whose output is raised or lowered (predominantly through the. use of automatic generating control equipment) as necessary to follow the moment-by-moment changes in load. The obligation to maintain this balance between resources and load lies with the Transmission Provider. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The Transmission Customer must either purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements to satisfy its Regulation and Frequency Response Service obligation. The amount of and charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service are set forth below.
1.1 Purchase Obligation For Loads Within MAIN The Regulation and Frequency Response Service Purchase Obligation shall be an amount equal to the Transmission Customer's allocated share, as defined below, of the "Adequate Regulating Margin" stated in the most recent Appendix A to MAIN Guide 5A for the Transmission Provider's Control Area; provided however, that Transmission Provider reserves the right to seek Commission approval under Section 205 of the Federal Power Act to establish a greater purchase obligation than such MAIN requirement, and such higher purchase obligation, upon approval by the Commission, shall be applicable to loads within such Control Area. The calculated Purchase Obligation shall be rounded to the nearest kW. The allocation factors to determine the Transmission Customer's share of the Control Area operator's "Adequate Regulating Margin," as stated in Appendix A to MAIN Guide 5A, shall be the Load Ratio Share for a Network Transmission Customer and the ratio of Reserved Capacity to Transmission Provider's monthly Transmission System Load as defined in Section 34.3 for a Point-to-Point Transmission Customer.
1.2 Reduction In Purchase Obligation The Transmission Customer's Purchase Obligation for this service shall be reduced by Regulation and Frequency Response Service provided by sources owned or purchased by the Transmission Customer where use of such sources for such purpose is: (1) responsive to the control signals of the Transmission Provider's Control Area; (2) consistent with the requirements of NERC, MAIN or any other successor organization and Good Utility Practice; and (3) evidence of the foregoing is provided to Transmission Provider. 2.0 The monthly Regulation and Frequency Response Service charge is up to $5,330/MW-Month times the Regulation and Frequency Response Service Purchase Obligation.
SCHEDULE 4Energy Imbalance Service Energy-Imbalance Service is provided when a difference occurs between the scheduled energy, including deliveries from operating reserves during a force majeure event necessary to complete scheduled deliveries, and the actual delivery of energy to a load located within a Control Area over a single hour. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The Transmission Customer must either purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements to satisfy its Energy Imbalance Service obligation. The Transmission Provider shall establish a deviation band of +/- 2.0 percent (with a minimum of 2 MW) of the scheduled transaction to be applied hourly to any energy imbalance that occurs as a result of the Transmission Customer's scheduled transaction(s). Transmission Provider and Transmission Customer will make arrangements to compensate each other for the hourly imbalances by cashing out the imbalance at 100% of the Energy Imbalance Cost as defined below. Energy imbalances outside the deviation band will be subject to charges to be specified by the Transmission Provider. The Energy Imbalance Cost ("EIC") for each hour shall be determined as follows: If the Transmission Provider is making single hour energy purchases during that hour, the EIC will be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy paid by the Transmission Provider for hourly energy during that hour. If the Transmission Provider is not engaged in any single hour energy purchases during the hour, the EIC shall be determined as follows: (a) For on-peak hours the EIC will be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy for all purchases occurring in that hour made by the Transmission Provider of 16 hours duration or less during the on-peak periods of the day in question; (b) for off-peak hours during on-peak days, the EIC will be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy for all purchases occurring in that hour made by the Transmission Provider of 8 hours or less during the off-peak hours of the day in question; (c) for all off-peak days the EIC shall be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy for all purchases occurring in that hour of 24 hours or less for the day in question. If there are no purchases as described above, the EIC for the hour in question shall be the incremental cost of operating the last generating unit supplying energy by the Transmission Provider. For purposes of this Schedule 4, on-peak and off-peak hours shall be as defined in NERC Operating Manual Appendix 1F, Inadvertent Interchange Energy Accounting Practices.
Oversupply by Transmission Customer When the Transmission Customer's scheduled receipt of energy for any hour is greater than the Transmission Customer's actual receipt of energy by an amount greater than 2.0%, the Transmission Provider will purchase such oversupply (i.e., any megawatt hour difference between the scheduled and received amounts greater than 2.0%) at a per megawatt hour rate of 90% of the Transmission Provider's hourly EIC except that, in the event that such oversupply condition causes an increase in the Transmission Provider's hourly EIC, the Transmission Provider will charge Transmission Customer at a rate of 110% of the increased costs incurred by the Transmission Provider as a result of such oversupply. An oversupply condition that causes an increase in the Transmission Provider's hourly EIC during a low load period occurs where oversupply causes the Transmission Provider to back down nuclear generation while the remaining on-line fossil generation is at minimum load. This situation also occurs when, to be able to operate fossil plants at a lower minimum load level, the Transmission Provider uses more expensive fuel or pays the operator of such fossil plants to use more expensive fuel.
Undersupply by Transmission Customer When the Transmission Customer's scheduled receipt of energy for any hour is less than the Transmission Customer's actual receipt of energy by an amount greater than 2.0% of the total energy scheduled to be received during that hour, the Transmission Provider will charge Transmission Customer for energy required to cover such undersupply (i.e., any megawatt hour difference between the received and scheduled amounts greater than 2.0%) at a per megawatt hour rate of 110% of the Transmission Provider's hourly EIC.
SCHEDULE 4ARetail Energy Imbalance Service 1.0 Retail Energy Imbalance Service is provided to Eligible Retail Customers taking unbundled transmission service. Retail Energy Imbalance Service is provided when a difference occurs between the scheduled energy, including deliveries from operating reserves during a force majeure event to the extent necessary to complete scheduled deliveries, and the actual delivery of energy to load located within a Control Area over a single hour. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area . The Transmission Customer must either purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements to satisfy its Energy Imbalance Service obligation. Eligible Retail Customers ("ERC") as used in this Schedule means those retail customers who are Eligible Customers as described in Section 1.11(ii), and take transmission service under the tariff.
2.0 The amount of energy imbalance shall be calculated separately for each hour and settlements will occur on a cash basis for each hour's imbalances. The imbalance of each ERC that is a Customer Self Manager shall be the aggregate imbalance of all retail load of that customer that is subject to this tariff. The imbalance of each ERC that is not a Customer Self Manager and that is purchasing electric power and energy from a RES who is a Transmission Customer shall be aggregated in each hour and the total aggregated imbalance shall be considered the retail imbalance of that RES under this Schedule 4A. The imbalance of each ERC that is taking service under Transmission Provider's State Rider PPO - Power Purchase Option ('PPO") or State Rider TS - Transition Service ("TS") shall be aggregated in each hour and the total aggregated imbalance shall be considered the retail imbalance of the Transmission Provider. The retail imbalance of the RES as defined herein shall be separate from, and shall not increase or decrease, any imbalance attributable to other load and from imbalances subject to Schedule 4. Imbalances determined pursuant to the provisions of this paragraph are referred to herein as "Retail Imbalances" of the Transmission Customer.
2.1 For Transmission Customers whose energy Retail Imbalance in an hour are within a deviation band of ± 2% (with a minimum of 2 MW), settlement shall be made at 100% of Energy Imbalance Cost ("EIC") as calculated in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 7.0 and 8.0 of this Schedule 4A, regardless of the net retail imbalance or the direction of such imbalance.
2.2 Those Transmission Customers, other than Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customers as defined in Schedule 4B, whose Retail Imbalances exceed 25% of their own individual schedules shall pay an adder or be credited using a discount of 25% of EIC. Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customers whose Retail Imbalances exceed the percentage of their own individual schedules determined under the provisions of Schedule 4B shall pay an adder or be credited using a discount of 25% of EIC. Adjustments shall be made to avoid double counting of adders and discounts applicable to those ERCs that are otherwise subject to the adder or discount provided in Paragraph 5.0 of this Schedule.
These imbalance costs will be phased-in as follows: a. From October 1, 1999 through December 31, 1999—no adder will apply under this paragraph 2.2. b. From January 1, 2000 through March 31, 2000—the 25% adder/discount will apply to those Transmission Customers whose Retail Imbalances exceed 25% of their schedules in 20% or more of the hours of the month. If the 20% of the hours are exceeded, the adder/discount shall apply to all hours in which the imbalance exceeded 25%. c. Starting April 1, 2000--the 25% adder/discount will apply to those Transmission Customers whose Retail Imbalances exceed 25% of their schedules in 10% or more of the hours of the month. If the 10% of the hours are exceeded, the adder/discount shall apply to all hours in which the imbalance exceeded 25%.
3.0 The Transmission Provider shall also apply a bandwidth to the total net Retail Imbalance of all Transmission Customers. If the hourly Retail Imbalance caused by all unbundled retail load, excluding those customers taking service under Transmission Provider's State Rider PPO and Transmission Provider's State Rider TS, is within the 100 MW bandwidth, no individual Transmission Customer (except those whose Retail Imbalance exceeds +/-25°%, as noted below) will be subject to an adder or discount. PPO/TS load will, in aggregate, be subject to the same terms and conditions as above, but imbalance-attributable to the PPO/TS load will be compared against a 100 MW bandwidth for PPO/TS load separately from other Retail Imbalances.
4.0 The Transmission Provider will permit Transmission Customers to trade Retail Imbalances, including those attributable to adders/discounts, among themselves, to offset their Retail Imbalances at whatever prices and terms they wish within a Trading Window, before Transmission Provider applies a charge for such Retail Imbalances. All remaining imbalances will be settled in cash at 100% of Transmission Provider's EIC. Transmission Provider shall make available information on EIC ten days prior to the opening of the trading window.
5.0 The net retail imbalance in excess of 100 MW will be charged an adder or discount of 10% of EIC. This charge will be allocated among ERCs who are out of balance in the direction of the net and whose imbalance exceeds their individual deviation band of +/- 2% (with a minimum of 2 MW). The allocation will be based on the ratio-share of the amount by which these individual Transmission Customers' retail imbalances exceed their individual deadbands. The ratio-share is the amount by which the individual Transmission Customer exceeds its deadband over the total amount by which those responsible for the charge under this paragraph exceeded their individual deadbands.
6.0 Retail imbalances will be assumed to be within the bandwidth (i.e., no adders/discounts) when the imbalances are due to (1) Transmission Provider interruptions and restorations, or (2) customer force majeure events, that are in each case material to the Transmission Customers' schedule and of which the Transmission Customer could not reasonably be aware in sufficient time to adjust the schedule.
7.0 The EIC for each hour shall be determined as follows: If the Transmission Provider is making single hour energy purchases during that hour, the EIC will be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy paid by the Transmission Provider for hourly energy during that hour. If the Transmission Provider is not engaged in any single hour energy purchases during the hour, the EIC shall be determined as follows: (a) For on-peak hours the EIC will be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy for all purchases occurring in that hour made by the Transmission Provider of 16 hours duration for less during the on-peak periods of the day in question; (b) for off-peak hours during on-peak days, the EIC will be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy for all purchases occurring in that hour made by the Transmission Provider of 8 hours or less during the off-peak hours of the day in question; (c) for all off-peak days the EIC shall be the megawatt-weighted average price of energy for all purchases occurring in that hour of 24 hours or less for the day in question. If there are no purchases as described above, the EIC for the hour in question shall be the incremental cost of operating the last generating unit supplying energy by the Transmission Provider. For purposes of this Schedule 4A, on-peak and off-peak hours shall be as defined in NERC Operating Manual Appendix 1F, Inadvertent Interchange
Energy Accounting Practices.
8.0 Oversupply: In the event that an oversupply condition exists on a net basis among all ERCs in any hour, and such oversupply condition causes an actual increase in the EIC of the Transmission Provider, then, instead of paying for such oversupply, Transmission Provider shall charge each Transmission Customer who incurred an oversupply for that hour a pro rata share of the actual increase in Transmission Provider's EIC based upon the ratio of that customer's energy oversupply to the total energy oversupply of all Transmission Customers who oversupplied for that hour. All other provisions of this Schedule 4A shall continue to apply. An oversupply condition that causes an increase in the Transmission Provider's hourly EIC during a low load period occurs where oversupply causes the Transmission Provider to back down nuclear generation while the remaining on-line fossil generation is at minimum load. This situation also occurs when, to be able to operate fossil plants at a lower minimum load level, the Transmission Provider uses more expensive fuel or pays the operator of such fossil plants to use more expensive fuel.
SCHEDULE 4B Optional Additional Load FollowingService for Non-Conforming Retail Loads
1.0 Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customers may choose to extend the 25% bandwidth specified in paragraph 2.2 of Schedule 4A in accordance with the rates, terms and conditions of this Schedule. This is an optional service and is not necessary in order for the transmission and distribution systems to function so that retail customers located in the Transmission Provider's service area can receive electric power and energy from suppliers other than the Transmission Provider.
