Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customers are: Customers (a) who operate or own facilities or equipment used in the metal melting, metal heating, or metal processing industries, including but not limited to the steel making and forging industries; and (b) whose average monthly maximum electrical demand on the Transmission Provider's system during the six of the last twelve calendar months with the customer's highest monthly maximum demands equals or exceeds 4 megawatts; and (c) who have highly variable and unpredictable loads such that the deviation between a good faith schedule for the customer and its actual load consistently falls outside of 25% of its schedule in at least 10% of the hours of a month; and (d) who have an individual retail energy imbalance calculation performed under Schedule 4A of this OATT by virtue of the Customer (i) being a Customer Self Manager or (ii) being served by a RES that, in accordance with the terms of this OATT, is authorized to and does submit a separate schedule for that Customer in each hour.
2.0 The 25% bandwidth may be extended on the following terms: a. The 25% bandwidth may be extended in intervals of 5% up to a maximum of 85%. b. Each 5% increase in such bandwidth will result in a requirement for Optional Additional Load Following Service for Non-conforming Retail Loads in megawatts of 20% times the Regulation and Frequency Response Service Purchase Obligation for the Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customer, as determined in Schedule 3. c. Optional Additional Load Following Service for Non-Conforming Retail Loads may be obtained from the Transmission Provider at the rates stated in Schedule 10 or may be obtained from any provider of such service. If obtained from the Transmission Provider, the cost for this optional service will be the rate stated in Schedule 10 times the megawatts determined in section 2.b, above. d. For service under this Schedule to be provided during months other than May, June, July, and August any Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customer may change on a calendar month basis the bandwidth extension of paragraph 2.a upon at least one month's prior notice. For service under this Schedule to be provided during the months of May, June, July, and August, any Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customer taking service under this Schedule may change on a calendar month basis the bandwidth extension of paragraph 2.a upon at least one month's prior notice provided that the Transmission Provider determines, in its sole discretion, that capacity to provide such load following can be obtained and that such change will not reduce the reliability of transmission service in the Transmission Provider's control area.
3.0 A customer taking service under this Schedule shall declare a duration of service at the time it requests service under this Schedule, provided that such term of service shall be not less than one year, nor more than three years. Service under this tariff shall be effective on the first day of the first month occurring not less than 30 days after the date that Non-conforming Load Transmission Customer notifies the Transmission Provider of its election to take service under this Schedule. Notwithstanding the above, Non-conforming Load Transmission Customers may notify the Transmission Provider on or before January 14, 2000, that it elects to take service under this Schedule effective February 1, 2000. 4.0 Except for extension of the 25% bandwidth, all other rates, terms and conditions of Schedule 4A shall apply to Non-Conforming Load Transmission Customers.
SCHEDULE 5 Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service
1. Spinning Reserve Service is needed to serve load immediately in the event of a system contingency. Spinning Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line and loaded at less than maximum output, ready to serve additional demand and which can be fully applied in 10 minutes. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The Transmission Customer must either purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements to satisfy its Spinning Reserve Service obligation. The amount of and charges for Spinning Reserve Service are set forth below.
1.1 Purchase Obligation The Spinning Reserve Service Purchase Obligation shall be an amount equal to the Transmission Customer's allocated share, as defined below, of the difference between the "Required Spinning Reserve" and the "Adequate Regulating Margin," each as stated in the most recent Appendix A to MAIN Guide 5A for the Transmission Provider's Control Area; provided however, that Transmission Provider reserves the right to seek Commission approval under Section 205 of the Federal Power Act to establish a greater purchase obligation than such Control Area. The calculated Purchase Obligation shall be rounded to the nearest kW. The allocation factors to determine the Transmission Customer's share of Transmission Provider's "Required Spinning Reserve" and "Adequate Regulating Margin," as stated in Appendix A to MAIN Guide 5A, shall be the Load Ratio Share for a Network Transmission Customer and the ratio of Reserved Capacity to Transmission Provider's monthly Transmission System Load as defined in Section 34.3 for a Point-to-Point Transmission Customer.
1.2 Reduction In Purchase Obligation The Transmission Customer's Purchase Obligation for this service shall be reduced by Spinning Reserve Service provided by sources owned or purchased by the Transmission Customer where use of such source for such purpose is: (1) responsive to the control signals of the Transmission Provider's Control Area or, if practical, responsive to communicated instruction; (2) consistent with the requirements of NERC, MAIN, or any other successor organization, and Good Utility Practice; and (3) evidence of the foregoing is provided to Transmission Provider. To the extent such reduction results in a Spinning Reserve Service Purchase Obligation of less than zero, such reduction below zero shall be considered to be excess spinning reserves and may be used to fulfill the Transmission Customer's Supplemental Reserve Service Purchase Obligation in accordance with Schedule 6 of this Tariff. 2. Compensation
2.1 Compensation for the supply of Spinning Reserve Service and associated Energy shall be made at the following rates: a. At the rate of up to $8,000 per Megawatt per month times the Spinning Reserve Service b. At the rate of up to $1,846 per megawatt per week timesthe Spinning Reserve Service Purchase Obligation, or c At the rate of up to $369 per megawatt per day times the Spinning Reserve Service Purchase Obligation, subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Spinning Reserve Service on any day in the seven-day period, and $1,846, or d. At the rate of up to $23.08 per megawatt per hour times the Spinning Reserve Service Purchase Obligation subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Spinning Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the seven-day period, and $1,846. In addition, the total demand charge in any day, shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Spinning Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the day, and $369. 2.2 Purchase of operating reserves by Transmission Customer from an entity other than Transmission Provider:
Transmission Customer may meet its spinning reserve obligation under this Schedule 5 by purchase of spinning reserve service from an entity other than Transmission Provider. The following terms shall apply to any such means of procuring required operating reserves: a. Source: Transmission Customer shall identify the specific generating units (including all units on a system) which are the source of the spinning reserve. The identified source of the spinning reserve must meet the spinning reserve criteria as stated in the then applicable MAIN Guide No. 5A. b. Delivery: Transmission Customer shall provide evidence to Transmission Provider of the existence of necessary transmission arrangements for firm delivery of power and energy from the identified source into the control area of Transmission Provider. Evidence of necessary delivery arrangements can include an OASIS reservation number for firm delivery, a service agreement under an open access transmission service tariff for firm delivery or other contractual arrangements for firm delivery. Transmission Provider may call for delivery of operating reserves whenever needed by the control area. c. Energy billing: When energy is delivered from operating reserves supplied by an entity other than Transmission Provider, the Transmission Customer shall bill the Transmission Provider for the resulting energy. In lieu of such arrangement and following notification, the operating reserve supplier may bill Transmission Provider; provided, however, that in no event shall any Transmission Customer or operating reserve supplier be authorized to bill Transmission Provider for such energy at a rate in excess of the incremental out of pocket cost of supplying the energy from the generating unit or units identified as the source of the operating reserves plus 10 percent. For a period of one year after submittal of a bill for energy delivered to Transmission Provider under this Paragraph 2.2, Transmission Provider shall have the right, consistent with usual commercial practices, to audit the cost basis for energy supplied and billed.
SCHEDULE 6 Operating Reserve - Supplemental Reserve Service
1. Supplemental Reserve Service is needed to serve load in the event of a system contingency; however, it is not. available immediately to serve load but rather within 10 minutes. Supplemental Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line but unloaded which can be fully applied in 10 minutes, by quick-start generation capable of serving demand within 10 minutes or by interruptible load that can be removed within 10 minutes. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The Transmission Customer must either purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements to satisfy its Supplemental Reserve Service obligation. The amount of and charges for Supplemental Reserve Service are set forth below.
1.1 Purchase Obligation The Supplemental Reserve Service Purchase Obligation shall be an amount equal to the Transmission Customer's allocated share, as defined below, of the "Allowable Non-Spinning Reserve" as stated in the most recent Appendix A to MAIN Guide 5A for Transmission Provider's Control Area; provided however, that Transmission Provider reserves the right to seek Commission approval under Section 205 of the Federal Power Act to establish a greater purchase obligation than such MAIN requirement, and such higher purchase obligation, upon approval by the Commission, shall be applicable to loads within such Control Area. The calculated Purchase Obligation shall be rounded to the nearest kW. The allocation factors to determine the Transmission Customer's share of Transmission Provider's "Allowable Non-Spinning Reserve," as stated in Appendix A to MAIN Guide 5A, shall be the load Ratio Share for a Network Transmission Customer, and the ratio of Reserved Capacity to Transmission Provider's monthly Transmission System Load as defined in Section 34.3 for a Point-to-Point Customer.
1.2 Reduction In Purchase Obligation The Transmission Customer's Purchase Obligation for this service shall be reduced by Supplemental Reserve Service provided by sources owned or purchased by the Transmission Customer where use of such source for such purpose is: (1) responsive to the control signals of the Transmission Provider's Control Area or, if practical, responsive to communicated instructions; (2) consistent with the requirements of NERC, MAIN, or any other applicable successor organization, and Good Utility Practice; and (3) evidence of the foregoing is provided to Transmission Provider. The Purchase Obligation may be reduced to the extent Transmission Customer has excess Spinning Reserve as defined in Schedule 5. 2. Compensation
2.1 Compensation for the supply of Supplemental Reserve Service and associated Energy shall be made at the following rates: a. At the rate of up to $2,260 per megawatt per month times the Supplemental Reserve Service Purchase Obligation, or b. At the rate of up to $521 per megawatt per week times the Supplemental Reserve Service Purchase Obligation, or c. At the rate of up to $104 per megawatt per day times the Supplemental Reserve Service Purchase Obligation, subject to the limitation that the total demand charge-in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Supplemental Reserve Service reserved on any day in the seven-day period, and $521, or d. At the rate of up to $6.52 per megawatt per hour times the Supplemental Reserve Service Purchase Obligation, subject to the limitation that the total demand charge in any consecutive seven-day period shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Supplemental Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the seven-day period, and $521. In addition, the total demand charge in any day shall not exceed the product of the highest number of megawatts of Supplemental Reserve Service reserved in any hour in the day, and $104.
2.2 Purchase of operating reserves by Transmission Customer from an entity other than Transmission Provider: Transmission Customer may meet its supplemental reserve obligation under this Schedule 6 by purchase of supplemental reserve service from an entity other than Transmission Provider. The following terms shall apply to any such means of procuring required operating reserves: a. Source: Transmission Customer shall identify the specific generating units (including all units on a system) which are the source of the supplemental reserve. The identified source of the supplemental reserve must meet the supplemental reserve criteria as stated in the then applicable MAIN Guide No. 5A. b. Delivery: Transmission Customer shall provide evidence to Transmission Provider of the existence of necessary transmission arrangements for firm delivery of power and energy from the identified source into the control area of Transmission Provider. Evidence of necessary delivery arrangements can include an OASIS reservation number for firm delivery, a service agreement under an open access transmission service tariff for firm delivery or other contractual arrangements for firm delivery. Transmission Provider may call for delivery of operating reserves whenever needed by the control area. c. Energy billing: When energy billing is delivered from operating reserves supplied by an entity other than Transmission Provider, the Transmission Customer shall bill the Transmission Provider for the resulting energy. In lieu of such arrangements and following notification, the operating reserve supplier may bill the Transmission Provider; provided, however, that in no event shall any Transmission Customer or operating reserve supplier be authorized to bill Transmission Provider for such energy at a rate in excess of the incremental out of pocket cost of supplying the energy from the generating unit or units identified as the source of the operating reserves plus 10 percent. For a period of one year after submittal of a bill for energy delivered to Transmission Provider under this Paragraph 2.2, Transmission Provider shall have the right, consistent with usual commercial practices, to audit the cost basis for energy supplied and billed.
SCHEDULE 7 Long-Term Firm and Short-Term Firm Point-To-PointTransmission Service The Transmission Customer shall compensate the Transmission Provider each month for Reserved Capacity at up to the sum of the applicable charges set forth below: 1) Yearly delivery: one-twelfth of the demand charge of $12.75/KW of Reserved Capacity per year. 2) Monthly delivery: $1.06/KW of Reserved Capacity per month. 3) Weekly delivery: $0.245/KW of Reserved Capacity per week. 4) Daily delivery: $0.049/KW of Reserved Capacity per day on any Monday through Friday, and up to $0.035/KW of Reserved Capacity per day on Saturdays, Sundays and the days on which the following holidays are generally observed: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day (National Holidays). The total demand charge in any week, pursuant to a reservation for Daily delivery, shall not exceed the rate specified in section (3) above times the highest amount in kilowatts of Reserved Capacity in any day during such week. All charges (yearly, monthly, weekly and daily delivery) set forth in this Schedule 7 are assessed against reserved capacity measured at point of delivery on the transmission system (i.e., reduced by the capacity losses in Section 15.7 of the Tariff). Gross receipts taxes and FERC annual charges (18 CFR § 382) shall apply in addition to the charges shown above. 5) Discounts: Three principal requirements apply to discounts for transmission service as follows (1) any offer of a discount made by the Transmission Provider must be announced to all Eligible Customers solely by posting on the OASIS, (2) any customer-initiated requests for discounts (including requests for use by one's wholesale merchant or an affiliate's use) must occur solely by posting on the OASIS, and (3) once a discount is negotiated, details must be immediately posted on the OASIS. For any discount agreed upon for service on a path, from point(s) of receipt to point(s) of delivery, the Transmission Provider must offer the same discounted transmission service rate for the same time period to all Eligible Customers on all unconstrained transmission paths that go to the same point(s) of delivery on the Transmission System.
SCHEDULE 8 Non-Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service The Transmission Customer shall compensate the Transmission Provider for Non-Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service up to the sum of the applicable charges set forth below: 1) Monthly delivery: $1.06/KW of Reserved Capacity per month. 2) Weekly delivery: $0.245/KW of Reserved Capacity per week. 3) Daily delivery: $0.049/KW of Reserved Capacity per day on any Monday through Friday, and up to $0.035/KW of Reserved Capacity per day on Saturdays, Sundays and the days on which the following holidays are generally observed: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day (National Holidays). The total demand charge in any week, pursuant to a reservation for Daily delivery, shall not exceed the rate specified in section (2) above times the highest amount in kilowatts of Reserved Capacity in any day during such week. 4) Hourly delivery: The basic charge shall be that agreed upon by the Parties at the time this service is reserved and in no event shall exceed $3.064/MWH during the On-Peak Period or $1.459/MWH during the Off-Peak Period which extends from midnight until 6 a.m. and 10 p.m. until midnight. The total demand charge in any day, pursuant to a reservation for Hourly delivery, shall not exceed the rate specified in section (3) above times the highest amount in kilowatts of Reserved Capacity in any hour during such day. All charges (monthly, weekly, daily, and hourly delivery) set forth in this Schedule 8 are assessed against reserved capacity measured at point of delivery on the transmission system (i.e., reduced by the capacity losses in Section 15.7 of the Tariff). Gross receipts taxes and FERC annual charges (18 CFR § 382) shall apply in addition to the charges shown above. 5) Discounts: Three principal requirements apply to discounts for transmission service as follows (1) any offer of a discount made by the Transmission Provider must be announced to all Eligible Customers solely by posting on the OASIS, (2) any customer-initiated requests for discounts (including requests for use by one's wholesale merchant or an affiliate's use) must occur solely by posting on the OASIS, and (3) once a discount is negotiated, details must be immediately posted on the OASIS. For any discount agreed upon for service on a path, from point(s) of receipt to point(s) of delivery, the Transmission Provider must offer the same discounted transmission service rate for the same time period to all Eligible Customers on all unconstrained transmission paths that go to the same point(s) of delivery on the Transmission System. Schedule 9 Redispatch for Non-Firm Transmission Service
The Transmission Customer shall compensate the Transmission Provider for Redispatch for Non-Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service, and transmission service for Network Customers from non-designated resources (Non-Firm Redispatch), as set forth below: 1. The greater of: (a) the charge for transmission service as agreed to by the Transmission Customer and the Transmission Provider and posted on the OASIS, plus (ii) losses, if supplied by the Transmission Provider, plus (iii) any charges incurred by the Transmission Provider for payments to third parties to redispatch; or (b) losses, if supplied by the Transmission Provider, plus (ii) any charges incurred by the Transmission Provider for payments to third parties to redispatch, plus (iii) the price quoted by the Transmission Provider on the OASIS for redispatching its own resources, plus (iv) 10% of the costs of b(iii). The charges under b(iv) will not exceed $10/Mwh.
2. Transmission Provider shall bill Transmission Customer the charge agreed upon with no subsequent adjustments.
3. When the Transmission Provider redispatches its own resources,the price quoted by the Transmission Provider on the OASIS of paragraph 1.b(iii) above shall be determined as follows: The sum of (1) the difference between (a) the estimated cost incurred to increase the output of out of merit units and (b) the estimated cost that would have been incurred in generating or purchasing the same amount of energy had Company not engaged in Non-Firm Redispatch; (2) the lost profit on sales foregone to accomplish the Non-Firm Redispatch. Company's lost profit is the difference between the sale price negotiated by Company and the estimated variable costs Company would have incurred in connection with the cancelled or interrupted sale; and (3) estimated costs incurred in modifying the maintenance schedule of one or more generators in order to operate those generators.
4. Upon written request of the Customer, Company shall provide the Customer with information sufficient to permit the Customer to verify its bill for Non-Firm Redispatch service. Unless otherwise mutually agreed, Company shall provide such information within 35 days of Company's receipt in writing of a request from Customer for such information. SCHEDULE 10 Optional Load Following Service for Non-Conforming Retail Loads
1 Optional Load Following Service for Non-Conforming Retail Loads is an optional service voluntarily offered by the Transmission Provider to allow eligible retail customers to manage the risk of imbalances by obtaining this service in exchange for a larger bandwidth. Optional Load Following Service for Non-Conforming Retail Loads may be provided by generating units that are on-line and loaded at less than maximum output, ready to serve additional demand and which can be fully applied in 10 minutes. The Transmission Customer may choose to purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements. The charges for Optional Load Following Service for Non-Conforming Retail Loads shall be up to the rates set forth below. Point-to-Point Transmission Service: $6,829/MW-month Network Integration Transmission Service: $6,829/MW-month Gross receipts taxes and FERC annual charges (18 CFR. § 382) shall apply in addition to the rates shown above. 2. If Optional Load Following Service for Non-Conforming Retail Loads is obtained from another provider, the resources providing this service shall be responsive to the control signals of the Transmission Provider's Control Area or, if practical, responsive to communicated instruction. 3. No transmission customer is required to take service under this Schedule 10 and customers electing this service may obtain it from any other qualified provider. Optional Load Following Service for Non-Conforming Retail Loads is thus not necessary in order for the transmission and .distribution systems to function so that retail customers located in the Transmission Provider's service area can receive electric power and energy from suppliers other than the Transmission Provider.
